title: Two independent systems extract the bleed air from the engin…
caption_en: Two independent systems extract the bleed air from the engines. They are the LP or low pressure bleed air system and the HP or high pressure bleed air system. The engine bleed system is controlled through the L BLEED and the R BLEED switches.

title: Since the left and right engine bleed systems are identical,…
caption_en: Since the left and right engine bleed systems are identical, we will refer only to the left bleed air system in this lesson.

title: Engine Bleed Valves and Switches The engine bleed air contro…
caption_en: Engine Bleed Valves and Switches The engine bleed air control valves are the environmental control system pressure regulating and shut-off valve (ECS PRSOV ) and the high pressure shut-off valve SOV).

title: When the engines are running, selecting the L BLEED switch o…
caption_en: When the engines are running, selecting the L BLEED switch opens the left ECS PRSOV and the OFF light on the L BLEED switch extinguishes. This action also arms the left HP SOV, the left emergency pressurization valve (EMER PRESS) and the left wing and stabilizer anti-ice valve.

title: This means that these armed valves (left HPSOV, left EMER PR…
caption_en: This means that these armed valves (left HPSOV, left EMER PRESS valve, left WingStab valve) require the Left Bleed switch to be selected on before they can open. The R BLEED switch controls the identical valves on the right side.

title: The EMER Press valve operation will be covered in the Pressu…
caption_en: The EMER Press valve operation will be covered in the Pressurization lesson. The Wing and Stabilizer valve will be covered in the Ice and Rain Protection lesson.

title: Low Pressure Bleed System. The LP air is bled from a single …
caption_en: Low Pressure Bleed System. The LP air is bled from a single port on the low pressure compressor section. With the engines running, this air flows through a check valve and stops between the left HP SOV and the ECS PRSOV. Both these left valves are controlled by the L BLEED switch.

title: The other part of the LP air stops at the emergency pressuri…
caption_en: The other part of the LP air stops at the emergency pressurization shut off vaive or EMER PRESS valve.

title: Selecting the L BLEED switch on, opens the left ECS PRSOV an…
caption_en: Selecting the L BLEED switch on, opens the left ECS PRSOV and its OFF light extinguishes. The LP air flow through another check valve into the pneumatic manifold. If the pack valve is open, the air flows into the ECU for cooling.

title: The LP air is used to supply the airplane bleed air requirem…
caption_en: The LP air is used to supply the airplane bleed air requirements during high thrust settings. This means during take-off, climb and cruise. Air for pressurizing the hydraulic reservoir is tapped from the pneumatic manifold. The right LP bleed air system is identical.

title: High Pressure Bleed System The HP bleed air is tapped from 4…
caption_en: High Pressure Bleed System The HP bleed air is tapped from 4 ports on the high pressure compressor section. This HP air flows and stops at the HP SOV. lt also stops at the WingStab anti-ice valve and the nacelle anti-ice shut-off valve (NAC SOV) on the engine.

title: The HP SOV operation depends on the bleed switch selection a…
caption_en: The HP SOV operation depends on the bleed switch selection and the thrust setting. With the L BLEED switch selected on, the left HP SOV opens during low thrust settings to boost the airflow into the cabin. This occurs after the engines are started, during taxy or a descent.

title: Note that the higher HP air pressure prevents the LP air fro…
caption_en: Note that the higher HP air pressure prevents the LP air from supplying bleed air at the same time. All the bleed air system requirements are now supplied by the HP air. When the thrust levers are pushed up for take-off, climb or cruise, the HP SOV automatically closes and the LP system takes over.

title: This is a summary of the bleed air usage. The HP air is used…
caption_en: This is a summary of the bleed air usage. The HP air is used during low thrust settings to prevent the engines from stalling. The LP air is used during high thrust settings.

title: Controller or Environmental Control System Controller (LearJ…
caption_en: Controller or Environmental Control System Controller (LearJet) The pneumatic system is controlled by the ECS controller This is a dual channel controller and controls the operation of the ECS PRSOVs, the HPSOVs and the EMER PRESS valves.

title: The left channel is powered by the DC Left Essential bus and…
caption_en: The left channel is powered by the DC Left Essential bus and controls the left ECS PRSOV, the left HPSOV and the left EMER PRESS valve. The right channel is powered by the DC Right Essential bus. It controls the similar valves on the right side.

title: Left Channel Failure If the left channel fails, both the lef…
caption_en: Left Channel Failure If the left channel fails, both the left HP SOV and the left EMER PRESS valves will automatically close if they are open. The left ECS PRSOV remains open if the L BLEED switch is left selected on.

title: The ECS PRSOV remains open if its controlling channel fails …
caption_en: The ECS PRSOV remains open if its controlling channel fails or if there is a loss of power to the valve itself. This is known as a Fail-Safe Open valve feature. This ensures that the LP pneumatic bleed is always available for pressurization. Note that the right HP air is now supplying the airplane bleed air system due to its higher pressure.

title: If the other channel also fails, the ECS controller will be …
caption_en: If the other channel also fails, the ECS controller will be inoperative. In this case, both the left and right HPSOV and the left and right EMER PRESS valves will close. However, both the ECS PRSOVs still remain open and the LP bleed air is used for air-conditioning and pressurization.
